articles.headline: For Bernie Sanders, Holding Onto Support May Be Hard in a 2020 Bid
articles.snippet: Mr. Sanders has not yet told advisers he intends to pursue another White House bid. But if he does, he will encounter a vastly different landscape than that of 2016.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sanders has not yet told advisers he intends to pursue another White House bid. But if he does, he will encounter a vastly different landscape than that of 2016.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some of his top congressional supporters won’t commit to backing him if he runs for president again — and two may join the 2020 race themselves. A handful of former aides might work for other candidates. And Bernie Sanders’s initial standing in Iowa polls is well below the 49.6 percent he captured in nearly defeating Hillary Clinton there in 2016.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Trump Unites Left and Right Against Troop Plans, but Puts Off Debate on War Aims
articles.snippet: A serious debate over the future of America’s wars is worth having. But the way President Trump made and announced his decisions snuffed out any opportunity.
articles.abstract: A serious debate over the future of America’s wars is worth having. But the way President Trump made and announced his decisions snuffed out any opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump managed to do something remarkable with his abrupt order last week to withdraw all American troops from Syria and half from Afghanistan: unite the left and right against a plan to extract the United States from two long, costly and increasingly futile conflicts.

articles.headline: Trump’s Tax Cut One Year Later: What Happened?
articles.snippet: Many corporations made good on promises to raise wages and pay bonuses. But others announced layoffs, even as the $1.5 trillion tax cut added billions to their bottom lines.
articles.abstract: Many corporations made good on promises to raise wages and pay bonuses. But others announced layoffs, even as the $1.5 trillion tax cut added billions to their bottom lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was a point in early 2018 when big American companies couldn’t stop talking about the Trump tax cuts. Flush with the projected savings from a $1.5 trillion law, they promised to raise wages, hand out bonuses to workers and invest in big projects. They scored headlines, along with applause from President Trump.

articles.headline: Inside Facebook’s Secret Rulebook for Global Political Speech
articles.snippet: Under fire for stirring up distrust and violence, the social network has vowed to police its users. But leaked documents raise serious questions about its approach.
articles.abstract: Under fire for stirring up distrust and violence, the social network has vowed to police its users. But leaked documents raise serious questions about its approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — In a glass conference room at its California headquarters, Facebook is taking on the bonfires of hate and misinformation it has helped fuel across the world, one post at a time.

articles.headline: With No Votes Scheduled, a Government Shutdown Will Greet the Democratic House
articles.snippet: The federal government will be partly shut down into the new year, Republicans announced, and the new Democratic leadership will have to get money flowing again.
articles.abstract: The federal government will be partly shut down into the new year, Republicans announced, and the new Democratic leadership will have to get money flowing again.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican leaders gave up hope on Thursday of reopening the government before the new year, leaving the border wall impasse to House Democrats as they assume the majority next week — and presenting Representative Nancy Pelosi with her first major challenge as speaker.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: Germany’s Far Right Rebrands: Friendlier Face, Same Doctrine
articles.snippet: A far-right youth movement is part of a growing network of actors giving extremism a friendly face — and worrying intelligence officials.
articles.abstract: A far-right youth movement is part of a growing network of actors giving extremism a friendly face — and worrying intelligence officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: HALLE, Germany — Christmas carols were playing and the scent of ginger hung in the crisp December air. Students sold organic plum compote and served mulled wine in biodegradable cups made from sugar cane. But then there were the postcards.

articles.headline: Tesla Scrambles to Sell Cars Before a Tax Break Fades
articles.snippet: Demand for the company’s electric cars could weaken in January, when a $7,500 federal tax credit is cut in half for buyers of Tesla’s luxury models.
articles.abstract: Demand for the company’s electric cars could weaken in January, when a $7,500 federal tax credit is cut in half for buyers of Tesla’s luxury models.
articles.lead_paragraph: This year, Mitch Mallin bought a metallic blue Tesla Model 3 sedan equipped with heated seats and a bevy of other options, all for $56,000 — twice as much as he had ever paid for a car before.

articles.headline: Sears Is Dying, but Workers’ Loyalty Lives On
articles.snippet: Across the country, legions of former employees gather regularly to celebrate a bygone era of retailing.
articles.abstract: Across the country, legions of former employees gather regularly to celebrate a bygone era of retailing.
articles.lead_paragraph: The annual Christmas luncheon was called for noon, but many members of the Atlanta Sears Family had arrived at the church hall by 10:30 a.m.

articles.headline: ‘I Feel Invisible’: Native Students Languish in Public Schools
articles.snippet: At Wolf Point High School in rural Montana, Native American students face the same neglect Native students across the U.S. do as they navigate a school system that has failed American Indians.
articles.abstract: At Wolf Point High School in rural Montana, Native American students face the same neglect Native students across the U.S. do as they navigate a school system that has failed American Indians.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported and written in a collaboration with ProPublica, the nonprofit investigative journalism organization.
articles.byline: By Erica L. Green, Annie Waldman and Annie Flanagan

articles.headline: China’s State Media Finds Good News in Underwear
articles.snippet: An unorthodox economic indicator points to an improving outlook in China’s rust belt. Economists are skeptical, but there are precedents for this kind of measurement.
articles.abstract: An unorthodox economic indicator points to an improving outlook in China’s rust belt. Economists are skeptical, but there are precedents for this kind of measurement.
articles.lead_paragraph: By almost any measure, China’s economy is slowing. Consumers are cautious. Apartments are sitting unsold. Industrial profits are falling, too.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

articles.headline: Syria’s Kurds, Feeling Betrayed by the U.S., Ask Assad Government for Protection
articles.snippet: Other powers in Syria have begun positioning themselves to take advantage of the vacuum left by a U.S. withdrawal.
articles.abstract: Other powers in Syria have begun positioning themselves to take advantage of the vacuum left by a U.S. withdrawal.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Feeling betrayed by the United States, its Kurdish allies in Syria asked the Syrian government on Friday to protect them from possible attack by Turkey.
